newsitem.title: HUNGARY: CSFB expects zero '97 tax for Borsodchem.
newsitem.headline: CSFB expects zero '97 tax for Borsodchem.

text.p: Hungarian chemicals company Borsodchem would probably be exempt of corporate taxes for 1997, Credit Suisse First Boston (CSFB) said in an update.
"We have assumed a zero percent corporate tax for this year," CSFB's Budapest-based analyst Spencer Jakab said in an update published on Thursday.
Borsodchem's CEO told Reuters on Wednesday they would meet all three criteria for a 100 percent corporate tax break for 1997 and CSFB also said it expects Borsodchem to meet the targets.

Zero tax rate is granted for the companies that are located in regions with over 10 percent unemployment, increase their exports by over 25 percent in 1997 or by a minimum 600 million forints and invested at least one billion forints last year.
On grounds of the expected tax relief, CSFB has raised Borsodchem's short-term target price to 5,600 to 5,700 forints and maintained its "buy" recommendation.
At 1113 GMT, Borsodchem shares stood at 5,500 forints on the Budapest Stock Exchange, up 45.
